en.alertText: The war in Ukraine, started by Russian aggression, has taken countless lives. Behind every statistic is a story—of a woman, a man, a child. This project aims to visualise the profound loss brought by war. Please take a moment and proceed only when you feel ready.
en.title:
The birdsong of sorrow
above Ukraine
en.leadText: Please take a moment here. The following visualizations depict lives lost in the ongoing Russian invasion of Ukraine and may be emotionally challenging. Proceed only if you feel ready.
en.ending: Day by day, the war continues, and birds appear on the canvas, reflecting lives lost. Even one is too many. This must end.

notes.subnote: Early on the morning of February 24, 2022 Russia launched a full-scale invasion of Ukraine
By June 2022, over 1,000 children had lost their lives
In August 2022, the total number of people who died reached 7000
By March 2022, 4,289 people, including 511 children, lost their lives, with devastating attacks across Ukraine, including in Bucha, Mariupol, and Irpin.</br>
notes.sourceText: (Monthly data comes from the UN Human Rights Office)

notes.subnote: In November 2022, the total number of people who died reached 8000
By November 2023, the total number of people who died reached 10 226
By May 2023, more than 1500 children had died, bringing the total death toll to 9281 people.
By May 2024, more than 1900 children had died, bringing the total death toll above 11 000 people.
As of October 2024, the last available number shows that 12,016 lives have been lost.
In August 2023, 30 children lost their lives during the ongoing war.
By April 2024, the World Health Organization verified 1,682 attacks on medical facilities, causing 128 deaths and 288 injuries.

notes.note: On the morning April 8, 2022, 71-year-old Tamara was at the Kramatorsk railway station with hundreds of others, waiting to evacuate. She planned to flee to Poland to reunite with her daughter when a missile strike hit the station, taking her life.
notes.subnote: At least 52 people, including five children, were killed and nearly 100 injured at the same attack.</br>

notes.note: On July 14, 2022, 4-year-old Liza Dmytriyeva, a girl with Down syndrome, was killed in a Russian missile strike in Vinnytsia while on her way to speech therapy. Her mother survived the attack.
notes.subnote: At least 23 people, including three children, were killed as Russian missiles struck Vinnytsia city center.

notes.note: On January 14, 2023, a Russian missile struck a 9-story residential building in Dnipro, killing at least 40 people, including three children, and injuring over 75. (United Nations)
11-year-old Sofia Shulha and her 6-year-old brother, Mykhayl,were likely asleep when they lost their lives as Russian missiles struck their home in Uman at 4 a.m. on April 28, 2023.
notes.subnote: The strike killed 23 civilians, including six children.

notes.note: Ukrainian writer Victoria Amelina, 37, and a war crimes researcher, was killed in a Russian missile strike on a pizza restaurant in Kramatorsk on June 27, 2023.
notes.subnote: The attack killed 13 people in total, including four children.

notes.note: Maksym and Alina Sirokurov died on October 5, 2023, when a Russian missile struck the small village of Hroza. They leave behind two young sons, aged 2 and 4.
notes.subnote: The missile strike in Hroza killed 59 people, a fifth of the village's population.

notes.note: On December 29, 2023, the attack killed 58 people and injured 160, targeting Kyiv, Odesa, Kharkiv, and Lviv, and damaging civilian infrastructure, homes, and schools.

On July 8, 2024, the Okhmatdyt Children's Hospital, the largest pediatric hospital in Kyiv, came under attack. More than 300 people were injured, including eight children,
and two adults, including a doctor, lost their lives. (New York Times)

On March 2, 2024, a Russian drone struck a nine-story residential building in Odesa. Anna Gaidarzhi and her four-month-old son, Tymofii, were found in the basement, buried under rubble after the upper floors collapsed. Anna’s husband, Serhii, and their three-year-old daughter, Lizzi, survived.
notes.subnote: According to the UN, the attack killed five children, most under the age of three, making it the deadliest incident for children in over nine months.

notes.note: On September 19, 2024, a Russian GPS-guided bomb struck Sumy’s care facility for the elderly. A 78-year-old woman was killed, and 12 others were injured in the attack.
notes.subnote: The Russian strike injured 12 people and caused significant destruction. The facility was home to 230 elderly residents and 60 staff members.
